language_tests.title: Language Tests
language_tests.description: Complete guides for all English and French language tests accepted for Canadian immigration

guides.title: IELTS General Training Complete Guide
guides.subtitle: International English Language Testing System - The Gold Standard
guides.overview: IELTS General Training is the most widely accepted English language test for Canadian immigration, with over 3.5 million test-takers annually. Required for Express Entry, Provincial Nominee Programs, and citizenship applications. This comprehensive guide covers everything from registration to achieving CLB 9+.

sections.name: Listening
tips: Read questions before audio plays
Write answers while listening
Check spelling carefully

sections.name: Reading
tips: Skim passages first
Don't spend too long on one question
Copy answers carefully

sections.name: Writing
sections.format: Task 1: Letter (150+ words), Task 2: Essay (250+ words)
tips: Manage time: 20 min Task 1, 40 min Task 2
Plan before writing
Leave time to check errors

sections.name: Speaking
tips: Speak naturally, don't memorize
Expand your answers
Ask for clarification if needed

crs_points.description: CRS points for first official language (English)

step_by_step.title: Choose Test Type
step_by_step.description: Select General Training (not Academic). Register online at ielts.org, britishcouncil.org, or idp.com.

step_by_step.title: Book Your Test
step_by_step.description: Choose paper-based or computer test. Computer tests have more frequent dates and faster results.

step_by_step.title: Prepare Effectively
step_by_step.description: Use official practice materials. Take full timed practice tests. Focus on weak areas.

step_by_step.title: Test Day
step_by_step.description: Bring passport/ID. Arrive early. Follow all instructions. Stay calm and focused.

step_by_step.title: Get Results
step_by_step.description: Results in 13 days (paper) or 5-7 days (computer). Access online and receive paper copy.

step_by_step.title: Send to IRCC
step_by_step.description: Results automatically available to IRCC for 2 years. Include in Express Entry profile.

tips: Practice with official IELTS materials from British Council or IDP
Focus on listening - you only hear recordings once
For writing, aim for clear structure: introduction, body paragraphs, conclusion
Speaking: Don't memorize answers - examiners can tell
Time management is crucial in Reading section - 20 min per passage
Take practice tests under real exam conditions
Computer tests have faster results - consider if time-sensitive
Book 4-6 weeks in advance at popular centers
If you need CLB 9, aim for consistent 7.0+ across all sections
common_mistakes: Taking Academic instead of General Training
Not completing all sections of the answer sheet
Exceeding word limits in Writing tasks
Using informal language in formal writing tasks
Not leaving time to transfer answers (paper-based)
Over-preparing Speaking with memorized answers
Ignoring one ability because you're strong in others
Not checking spelling in Listening answers

score_improvement.strategy: Focus on Writing and Speaking which have lower score benchmarks
Intensive practice on Reading comprehension and vocabulary
Perfect your weakest ability - every 0.5 band counts

guides.title: IELTS Academic Complete Guide
guides.subtitle: For Study Permits, Professional Licensing & Graduate Programs
guides.overview: IELTS Academic is designed for students seeking admission to universities and colleges in Canada, as well as professionals requiring registration with regulatory bodies. While General Training is used for immigration, Academic IELTS is essential for study permits and professional pathways. This guide covers everything you need to know about the Academic version.

key_facts.use_cases: Study permits, university admission, professional registration

when_to_use.study_permit: Required by most Canadian universities and colleges for international students
when_to_use.not_for_immigration: Express Entry and PR applications require General Training, NOT Academic

sections.name: Listening
tips: Listen for signpost words like 'however', 'firstly'
Section 3 and 4 are academic contexts
Practice with lectures and academic discussions

sections.name: Reading
tips: Texts are more complex than General Training
Practice with academic journals and research papers
Learn to identify writer's opinion vs. factual information

sections.name: Writing
sections.format: Task 1: Describe visual data (150+ words), Task 2: Academic essay (250+ words)
tips: Task 1: Charts, graphs, diagrams, maps or processes
Use academic vocabulary and formal register
Task 2 is worth twice as much as Task 1

sections.name: Speaking
tips: Part 3 involves abstract discussion on academic topics
Use sophisticated vocabulary where appropriate
Support your opinions with examples

academic_vs_general.description: Key differences between Academic and General Training IELTS

reading.academic: 3 long academic texts from books, journals, magazines
reading.general: Shorter texts from everyday sources - ads, manuals, notices

writing_task_1.academic: Describe chart, graph, table, diagram, map or process
writing_task_1.general: Write a letter (formal, semi-formal, or informal)

difficulty.academic: More challenging reading and writing tasks

scoring.general: Same scale but different raw score conversion

step_by_step.title: Verify Requirement
step_by_step.description: Confirm your university/institution requires Academic IELTS (not General Training). Check specific band score requirements.

step_by_step.title: Register for Test
step_by_step.description: Book at ielts.org, British Council, or IDP. Choose paper or computer-based. Book 4-6 weeks in advance.

step_by_step.title: Master Task 1 Writing
step_by_step.description: Practice describing graphs, charts, and processes. Learn vocabulary for trends, comparisons, and data description.

step_by_step.title: Build Academic Vocabulary
step_by_step.description: Study Academic Word List (AWL). Read academic journals and textbooks. Practice paraphrasing.

step_by_step.title: Practice with Cambridge Books
step_by_step.description: Use official Cambridge IELTS Academic practice tests (Books 14-18). Take full timed tests.

step_by_step.title: Take the Test
step_by_step.description: Bring passport, arrive early. Manage time carefully in Reading section.

step_by_step.title: Send Results
step_by_step.description: Request additional Test Report Forms (TRFs) be sent to your institutions. Some accept online verification.

tips: Read academic journals like The Economist, Nature, or Scientific American for reading practice
For Task 1, memorize vocabulary for describing trends: 'increased sharply', 'fluctuated', 'remained stable'
Practice writing under timed conditions - many students run out of time
Learn to quickly identify question types: True/False/Not Given, Matching Headings, Summary Completion
For graphs and charts, always describe the main trend first before details
Use transition words to show relationships between ideas in essays
Speaking Part 3 tests abstract thinking - practice discussing societal issues
Many universities have specific requirements per band - check your program carefully
common_mistakes: Taking General Training instead of Academic (they are NOT interchangeable)
Describing every detail in Task 1 instead of key trends and comparisons
Using informal language in academic writing
Not reaching minimum word count (150/250 words)
Spending too long on Task 1 (only worth 1/3 of writing score)
Not practicing with authentic academic reading materials
Forgetting to state your own opinion in Task 2 essays
Assuming Speaking is the same - Part 3 is more abstract in Academic context

guides.title: CELPIP General Complete Guide
guides.subtitle: Canadian English Language Proficiency Index Program
guides.overview: CELPIP is designed specifically for Canadian immigration and citizenship. It's fully computer-based with Canadian accents and contexts, making it ideal for those already familiar with Canadian English. Results in just 4-5 business days!

key_facts.test_type: General (for PR) or General LS (for citizenship)

sections.name: Listening
sections.format: Canadian accents, workplace and social situations
tips: Headphones provided - adjust volume before starting
You can replay audio once in some sections

sections.name: Reading
tips: Skim first, then read carefully for answers
Time shown on screen - manage it well

sections.name: Writing
tips: Use templates for common formats
Type naturally - spell check not available

sections.name: Speaking
tips: Speak clearly and at moderate pace
Use full preparation time provided

clb_conversion.info: CELPIP scores directly correspond to CLB levels

advantages_over_ielts: Direct CLB scores - no conversion needed
Entire test done on computer in one sitting

step_by_step.title: Register Online
step_by_step.description: Create account at celpip.ca. Choose General (for PR) or General LS (citizenship only).

step_by_step.title: Book Test
step_by_step.description: Select test center and date. Pay $280-$340 CAD. Slots fill quickly - book early.

step_by_step.title: Prepare
step_by_step.description: Use free CELPIP practice tests online. Familiarize with computer format.

step_by_step.title: Test Day
step_by_step.description: Bring valid ID. Test is 3 hours in one sitting. All sections on computer.

step_by_step.title: Receive Results
step_by_step.description: Results in 4-5 business days via email. Scores valid for 2 years.

step_by_step.title: Add to Profile
step_by_step.description: Enter scores in Express Entry. Results automatically shared with IRCC.

tips: Familiarize yourself with Canadian accents and expressions
Practice with CELPIP's free online resources before test
The speaking section is recorded - speak clearly into the microphone
Writing tasks have specific formats - learn them beforehand
Results come within 4-5 business days - great for tight deadlines
You can retake after just 4 days if needed
Use the notepad feature during Listening section
Practice typing - the Writing section requires good typing speed
common_mistakes: Not practicing with computer-based format beforehand
Ignoring Canadian cultural references in practice
Speaking too fast or too slow in Speaking section
Not using the full time for Writing tasks
Forgetting to check microphone before Speaking
Panicking if you make a mistake - you can't go back

guides.title: PTE Core Complete Guide
guides.subtitle: Pearson Test of English Core - Fast Results for PR
guides.overview: PTE Core is the newest accepted English test for Canadian immigration, launched in 2024. Fully computer-scored with AI technology, it offers the fastest results - typically within 48 hours! Perfect for those comfortable with technology.

sections.name: Speaking & Writing
sections.format: Combined section - speaking recorded, writing typed

sections.name: Reading
sections.format: Fill blanks, multiple choice, reorder paragraphs

clb_conversion.info: PTE Core uses a 10-90 scale converted to CLB

advantages: No human examiner for Speaking - less anxiety

step_by_step.title: Create Account
step_by_step.description: Register at pearsonpte.com. Make sure you select PTE Core, not Academic.

step_by_step.title: Book Test
step_by_step.description: Choose date and center. Tests available frequently. Pay online.

step_by_step.title: Practice
step_by_step.description: Use official PTE practice platform. AI scoring means consistency matters.

step_by_step.title: Test Day
step_by_step.description: Arrive early. Test is 2 hours total. Speak clearly for AI scoring.

step_by_step.title: Get Results
step_by_step.description: Results typically within 48 hours! Access online scorecard.

step_by_step.title: Send to IRCC
step_by_step.description: Send unlimited official score reports. Add to Express Entry profile.

tips: Computer scores everything - clarity matters more than accent
Speak at a natural pace, not too fast or slow
Results in 48 hours - great for tight deadlines
Practice with AI scoring tools to understand the system
The microphone picks up background noise - speak close to it
Use templates for essay structure
Don't leave any question unanswered
common_mistakes: Speaking too quickly - AI may not understand
Not finishing within time limits
Hesitating too long before speaking
Using filler words excessively
Not practicing with the computer interface

credential_evaluation.title: Credential Evaluation
credential_evaluation.description: How to get your foreign education recognized in Canada

guides.title: WES ECA Complete Guide
guides.subtitle: World Education Services - Educational Credential Assessment
guides.overview: WES is the most popular credential evaluation service for Canadian immigration. Required for Express Entry if you studied outside Canada. This guide covers the complete process from application to receiving your ECA.

key_facts.accepted_for: Express Entry, most PNPs, some employers

eca_vs_general.description: For Canadian immigration, you MUST select ECA not general evaluation
eca_vs_general.eca: Educational Credential Assessment - recognized by IRCC
eca_vs_general.general: For employment/licensing only - NOT accepted for immigration

step_by_step.title: Create WES Account
step_by_step.description: Go to wes.org/ca (CANADA site, not USA). Create account and select 'ECA Application for IRCC'. This is critical - general evaluation won't work for immigration.

step_by_step.title: Pay Fees
step_by_step.description: $256 CAD for ECA evaluation. Standard delivery $13 CAD, Courier $28-95 CAD. Add extra copies if needed for PNP applications.

step_by_step.title: Get Reference Number
step_by_step.description: Write this number on ALL documents. Include it in any communication with your university. This links your documents to your application.

step_by_step.title: Order Documents from Institution
step_by_step.description: Transcripts MUST be sent directly from your university to WES in a sealed envelope. Many universities have online systems. Degree can be uploaded as PDF.

step_by_step.title: Track Document Arrival
step_by_step.description: Monitor status at wes.org. You'll see when each document arrives. Contact institution if delays occur.

step_by_step.title: Receive ECA Report
step_by_step.description: Processing takes 7 business days after all docs received. Digital report sent automatically to IRCC. Paper copy mailed to you.

india: All transcripts (request via DigiLocker or from university)
Provisional degree if final not yet issued
Consolidated marksheet if individual marksheets unavailable
china: Verification report from CHESICC or CDGDC
philippines: Send via WES required sealed envelopes

tips: Start the WES process BEFORE you need it - allow 8-12 weeks total
Use FedEx or UPS for international shipping (DHL has customs issues in Canada)
Only submit your highest credential - you don't need every degree
For India, DigiLocker is the fastest way to get verified transcripts
Keep tracking numbers for everything you send
WES Canada and WES USA are separate - make sure you use the Canada site
If your university is not on WES list, check IQAS as an alternative
common_mistakes: Using WES USA site instead of WES Canada
Forgetting to write reference number on documents
Sending transcripts yourself instead of through institution
Selecting general evaluation instead of ECA
Not ordering enough copies (need for PNP applications)
Waiting until last minute - documents take time
Not checking if your institution is recognized by WES

alternatives.name: IQAS
alternatives.best_for: Alberta PNP specifically, some degrees WES doesn't cover

guides.title: IQAS (Alberta) ECA Guide

key_facts.accepted_for: Express Entry, Alberta PNP, other PNPs

when_to_use_iqas: Your country/institution not recognized by WES

express_entry.title: Express Entry
express_entry.description: Canada's flagship immigration system for skilled workers

guides.title: Express Entry Complete Guide 2025
guides.subtitle: Everything You Need to Know About Canada's Fastest PR Pathway
guides.overview: Express Entry is Canada's flagship points-based immigration system, managing three federal economic programs. Most successful applicants receive Permanent Residence in 6 months or less! This comprehensive guide covers everything from eligibility to maximizing your CRS score.

programs.name: Federal Skilled Worker Program (FSWP)
programs.description: For skilled workers with foreign work experience
requirements: CLB 7 in all four language abilities
1+ year continuous skilled work experience (NOC TEER 0, 1, 2, or 3)
Educational Credential Assessment (ECA) for foreign education
Proof of settlement funds (unless working in Canada)
programs.best_for: Professionals applying from outside Canada with foreign work experience

programs.name: Canadian Experience Class (CEC)
programs.description: For temporary workers and graduates already in Canada
requirements: CLB 7 for NOC TEER 0/1, CLB 5 for TEER 2/3
1+ year skilled work experience in Canada within last 3 years
Currently in Canada or leaving for PR (no funds required)
programs.best_for: International students with PGWP, temporary foreign workers in Canada

programs.name: Federal Skilled Trades Program (FSTP)
requirements: 2+ years full-time skilled trades experience in last 5 years
Valid job offer (2+ years) OR trade certificate from province
Meet job requirements for the trade
programs.best_for: Electricians, plumbers, welders, construction trades, chefs

core_factors.title: Core/Human Capital Factors (max 500 with spouse, 600 without)

improvement_strategies.details: Retaking IELTS/CELPIP to move from CLB 7 to CLB 9 can add 50+ points. This is often the fastest CRS boost. Focus on your weakest ability.
NCLC 7 in French + CLB 5 in English = 50 bonus points. Plus you become eligible for French-focused draws with cutoffs around 400-450.
A PNP nomination adds 600 points, virtually guaranteeing an invitation. Research all provinces - many don't require a job offer.
Each year of Canadian experience adds significant points. Plus it opens up CEC pathway which often has lower cutoffs.
A Canadian diploma or degree adds points directly, plus unlocks PGWP for work experience. Consider fast-track programs.
If your spouse has high language/education scores, they add points. If not, applying without spouse might give higher score.

step_by_step.title: Check Eligibility
step_by_step.description: Determine which program(s) you qualify for: FSWP, CEC, or FSTP. You can be eligible for multiple programs.

step_by_step.title: Take Language Test
step_by_step.description: IELTS General Training, CELPIP, or PTE Core for English. TEF/TCF for French. Results valid 2 years.

step_by_step.title: Get ECA
step_by_step.description: If you studied outside Canada, get your education assessed by WES, IQAS, or another designated organization.

step_by_step.title: Create Express Entry Profile
step_by_step.description: Enter all information accurately. Calculate your CRS score. Profile valid for 12 months.

step_by_step.title: Improve Your Score
step_by_step.description: While in the pool, work on improving CRS. Retake language tests, apply to PNPs, consider French.

step_by_step.title: Receive ITA
step_by_step.description: When your CRS is above the cutoff, you receive an Invitation to Apply. You have 60 days to submit full application.

step_by_step.title: Submit PR Application
step_by_step.description: Gather all documents: police certificates, medical exam, work experience letters, education documents.

step_by_step.title: Wait for Decision
step_by_step.description: Processing typically 6 months. You may be asked for additional documents. Track status online.

step_by_step.title: Receive COPR
step_by_step.description: Confirmation of Permanent Residence! Complete landing and get PR card.

tips: Create your profile even if CRS seems low - you never know when cutoffs will drop
Watch category-based draws - healthcare, STEM, French, trades have lower cutoffs
French proficiency is increasingly valuable - even intermediate French helps
Keep language test results updated - don't let them expire while in pool
Apply to multiple PNPs simultaneously - increases your chances
Have all documents ready BEFORE you get ITA - 60 days goes fast
Medical exams can be done upfront (valid 12 months)
Police certificates take time from some countries - start early
Proofread everything - errors can delay your application
common_mistakes: Not including all work experience (every month counts)
Wrong NOC code classification for jobs
Language test results not from designated organization
ECA showing lower education than expected
Incomplete work experience reference letters
Missing documents with 60-day ITA deadline
Not updating profile when circumstances change
Assuming job offer guarantees success (LMIA removed March 2025)

guides.title: CRS Score Calculator & Improvement Guide
guides.subtitle: Understand and Maximize Your Comprehensive Ranking System Score
guides.overview: The Comprehensive Ranking System (CRS) is how Express Entry candidates are ranked. This guide breaks down exactly how points are calculated and actionable strategies to improve your score.
tips: Use the official IRCC CRS calculator to know your exact score
Even 1 point can make the difference in competitive draws
Category-based draws have significantly lower cutoffs
French proficiency is the fastest way to boost score if you have time

atlantic_immigration.title: Atlantic Immigration Program
atlantic_immigration.description: Special program for Atlantic Canada's four provinces - no LMIA required!

guides.title: Atlantic Immigration Program (AIP) Complete Guide
guides.subtitle: Fast-Track to PR in Atlantic Canada - No LMIA Required!
guides.overview: The Atlantic Immigration Program (AIP) is an employer-driven pathway to permanent residence in Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island, and Newfoundland and Labrador. Major advantage: NO LMIA required! Employers can hire faster and you can get PR faster.

key_facts.provinces: Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, PEI, Newfoundland
key_facts.lmia_required: NO - this is a major advantage

requirements.details: Employer must be designated by the Atlantic province. 1-year duration for most, permanent for skilled workers.
In the last 5 years, in occupation matching NOC of job offer. Can be from inside or outside Canada.
CLB 5 for NOC TEER 0, 1, 2, 3. CLB 4 for NOC TEER 4.
High school minimum. If foreign, need ECA. Must be equivalent to Canadian high school or higher.
Required only if not currently living and working in Canada. Funds depend on family size.

benefits: No LMIA required - employers save time and money
Work permit while PR application processes
Faster than regular Express Entry for many
Lower cost of living in Atlantic provinces

step_by_step.title: Find Designated Employer
step_by_step.description: Search for jobs with employers designated under AIP. They can hire you without LMIA.

step_by_step.title: Receive Job Offer
step_by_step.description: Get valid job offer in eligible occupation. Must be full-time, non-seasonal.

step_by_step.title: Settlement Plan
step_by_step.description: Complete Needs Assessment with designated settlement service provider.

step_by_step.title: Provincial Endorsement
step_by_step.description: Employer submits your application to provincial immigration office for endorsement.

step_by_step.title: Apply for Work Permit
step_by_step.description: With endorsement letter, apply for employer-specific work permit to start working.

step_by_step.title: Apply for PR
step_by_step.description: Submit permanent residence application with endorsement letter.

step_by_step.title: Receive PR
step_by_step.description: Processing typically 12 months. Continue working while application processes.

eligible_occupations: International graduates of Atlantic institutions have additional options
tips: Check if employer is designated before accepting job offer
Settlement plan is REQUIRED - don't skip this step
You can work while PR application is processing
Your spouse can work anywhere in Canada with open work permit
Atlantic provinces have lower cost of living than Toronto/Vancouver
AIP to PR is often faster than Express Entry for those with job offers
common_mistakes: Working for non-designated employer (must be designated)
Skipping the settlement plan (it's mandatory)
Not meeting language requirements before applying
Job offer not matching work experience NOC
Not having proof of funds (if required)

forms_guides.title: Form Filling Guides
forms_guides.description: Step-by-step guides for all IRCC immigration forms

guides.title: IMM 0008 - Generic Application Form Complete Guide
guides.subtitle: The Main PR Application Form - Step by Step
guides.overview: IMM 0008 is the primary application form for Canadian permanent residence. Every PR applicant must complete it. The form generates barcodes when validated - these are REQUIRED for processing. This guide covers every section in detail.

key_facts.format: PDF - must open in Adobe Reader
key_facts.updates: Check for latest version on IRCC website

before_you_start: Download the latest version from IRCC website
Use Adobe Reader 10 or higher (not Preview on Mac)
Gather all documents: passport, work letters, education certificates
Have address history ready (all addresses for 10 years)

sections.tips: Names MUST match passport exactly. Include all names used.
Use an email you check regularly - IRCC will contact you here.
Passport must be valid for at least 6 months after expected PR date.
Include ALL family members, even if not accompanying you to Canada.

fields: All education from secondary school onwards
sections.tips: Include education even if not related to your occupation.
NO GAPS - if unemployed, explain (studying, job searching, etc.).

step_by_step.title: Download Form
step_by_step.description: Get IMM 0008 from IRCC website. Ensure you have the latest version for your program.

step_by_step.title: Open in Adobe Reader
step_by_step.description: Must use Adobe Reader, not other PDF viewers. Features won't work otherwise.

step_by_step.title: Complete All Sections
step_by_step.description: Fill every applicable field. Use 'N/A' or 'None' where appropriate.

step_by_step.title: Validate Form
step_by_step.description: Click 'Validate' button. This generates barcode pages. Without barcodes, application REJECTED.

step_by_step.title: Save and Print
step_by_step.description: Save the validated PDF. Print all pages including barcode pages.

step_by_step.title: Sign and Date
step_by_step.description: Sign the declaration page. Date must match submission date.

tips: Always use the official form from IRCC website - old versions rejected
Click 'Validate' button to generate barcodes - this is CRITICAL
Include all family members even if not coming to Canada
Names must match passport EXACTLY - check spelling carefully
Form cannot be handwritten - must be typed
Keep a copy of everything you submit
If married, spouse must also fill out their own forms
common_mistakes: Missing barcode pages (form not validated)
Using initials instead of full legal names
Inconsistent dates between different forms
Not listing all family members
Gaps in work history without explanation
Using old version of the form
Opening in non-Adobe PDF reader

guides.title: IMM 5669 - Schedule A Background Declaration
guides.subtitle: Personal History and Background Form
guides.overview: Schedule A (IMM 5669) declares your personal history including all addresses, employment, education, military service, and organizational memberships. Accuracy and completeness are critical - inconsistencies can cause delays or refusal.

what_to_include: Dates must be consecutive - no gaps
sections.tips: Even temporary addresses (hotels, staying with family) should be included if you were there for extended periods.
Explain gaps: 'Unemployed - seeking work' or 'Stay-at-home parent'

what_to_include: Any military, militia, or civil defence service

sections.tips: Include everything - IRCC will check. Being honest is better than hiding memberships.

tips: List ALL addresses for past 10 years with no gaps
Include all employment with no gaps - explain unemployment
List all organizations/memberships - even sports clubs
Account for ALL time periods - every month must be covered
Use separate sheet if you need more space
Dates must be consistent with IMM 0008
Both you AND your spouse must complete separate forms
common_mistakes: Gaps in timeline - every month must be accounted for
Missing addresses (forgot about temporary housing)
Forgetting volunteer organizations or clubs
Inconsistent dates with other forms
Not including all family members as required
Leaving sections blank instead of writing 'None'

guides.title: IMM 5406 - Additional Family Information
guides.subtitle: Detailed Family Member Information Form
guides.overview: IMM 5406 collects detailed information about your immediate family including parents, siblings, and children. Both applicant and spouse complete separate copies of this form.

key_facts.copies_needed: Two: one for principal, one for spouse

who_to_include: Your mother and father (biological or adoptive)
required_information: Full names in native alphabet AND English
tips: Complete TWO copies: one for you, one for your spouse
Write names in native alphabet AND English/French
Include deceased family members (mark as deceased)
List current addresses for ALL relatives
If you don't know information, write 'Unknown'
Be consistent with names across all forms
common_mistakes: Submitting only one copy (both spouses need to fill it)
Not including names in native script
Forgetting deceased family members
Inconsistent information with other forms
Missing siblings (including half-siblings)

guides.title: IMM 5562 - Supplementary Travel Document
guides.subtitle: Complete Travel History Form
guides.overview: IMM 5562 requires you to list all international travel for the past 10 years. This includes every trip outside your country of residence, even short visits.
what_to_include: Purpose of travel (tourism, work, study, etc.)
tips: Check passport stamps for accurate dates
Include short trips (even 1-day border crossings)
List trips in chronological order
If you can't remember exact dates, use approximate
Include trips on expired passports
Business trips, vacations, family visits - include all
common_mistakes: Forgetting short trips or day visits
Inaccurate dates (check passport stamps)
Missing trips from expired passports
Not including transit stops in other countries

guides.title: IMM 5476 - Use of a Representative
guides.subtitle: Authorizing a Representative Form
guides.overview: IMM 5476 authorizes someone to act on your behalf with IRCC. This could be an immigration consultant (RCIC), lawyer, or unpaid family member/friend.

key_facts.requirement: Must be RCIC if paid in Canada

paid_vs_unpaid.paid_representative: Must be licensed RCIC or lawyer. Check College-IC.ca to verify. IRCC will communicate with them directly.
paid_vs_unpaid.unpaid_representative: Family member or friend helping for free. Limited to providing info, not legal advice.

tips: Only use licensed RCICs or lawyers for paid help
Verify RCIC license at college-ic.ca before hiring
You can cancel representative authorization anytime
You still receive copies of all correspondence
Form must be signed by BOTH you AND the representative
common_mistakes: Using unlicensed immigration consultant (fraud)
Not signing both sections of the form
Forgetting to include representative's license number
